DataElement.preferredName: Pulmonary Function Test Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second Reproducibility Result
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that represents the reproducibility of the Forced Expiratory Volume in one second (FEV1) exam.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Pulmonary Function Test Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second Reproducibility
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A broad range of tests that are performed to assess how well lungs inhale and exhale air and how efficiently they transfer oxygen into the blood._A test of lung function, the FEV1 is the volume exhaled during the first second of a forced expiratory maneuver started from the level of total lung capacity. It is the most frequently used index for assessing bronchoconstriction or bronchodilatation._The ability to yield similar results given a set of constraints.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A broad range of tests that are performed to assess how well lungs inhale and exhale air and how efficiently they transfer oxygen into the blood.

Concepts.definition: A broad range of tests that are performed to assess how well lungs inhale and exhale air and how efficiently they transfer oxygen into the blood.

Property.preferredName: Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second Reproducibility
Property.preferredDefinition: A test of lung function, the FEV1 is the volume exhaled during the first second of a forced expiratory maneuver started from the level of total lung capacity. It is the most frequently used index for assessing bronchoconstriction or bronchodilatation.:The statistical reproducibility of measurements (often in a clinical context), including the testing of instrumentation or techniques to obtain reproducible results. The concept includes reproducibility of physiological measurements, which may be used to develop rules to assess probability or prognosis, or response to a stimulus; reproducibility of occurrence of a condition; and reproducibility of experimental results.

Concepts.definition: A test of lung function, the FEV1 is the volume exhaled during the first second of a forced expiratory maneuver started from the level of total lung capacity. It is the most frequently used index for assessing bronchoconstriction or bronchodilatation.
The ability to yield similar results given a set of constraints.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
